elements.content: A new highly stable copper­(I)-based metal–organic framework (MOF), namely, [CuI 4(SiW12O40)­(L)]·6H2O·2DMF (1), was synthesized by incorporating Keggin-type polyoxometalate (POM) anions and a functionalized wheel-like resorcin[4]­arene-based ligand (L) under sovothermal condition. 1 exhibits a charming 3D supramolecular architecture sandwiched by the POM anions. Noticeably, 1 has exceptional chemical stability, especially in organic solvents or aqueous solutions with a wide range of pH values. Considering the catalytically active Cu­(I) sites in 1, the azide–alkyne cycloaddition (AAC) reaction was studied by employing 1 as the heterogeneous catalyst. Most strikingly, 1 exhibits excellent catalytic activity as well as recyclability for the AAC reaction.
elements.clean_text: A new highly stable copper(I)-based metal-organic framework (MOF), namely, [CuI 4(SiW12O40)(L)]⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (1), was synthesized by incorporating Keggin-type polyoxometalate (POM) anions and a functionalized wheel-like resorcin[4]arene-based ligand (L) under sovothermal condition. 1 exhibits a charming 3D supramolecular architecture sandwiched by the POM anions. Noticeably, 1 has exceptional chemical stability, especially in organic solvents or aqueous solutions with a wide range of pH values. Considering the catalytically active Cu(I) sites in 1, the azide-alkyne cycloaddition (AAC) reaction was studied by employing 1 as the heterogeneous catalyst. Most strikingly, 1 exhibits excellent catalytic activity as well as recyclability for the AAC reaction.

elements.content: Copper­(I)-catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC), as a powerful one-pot “click” reaction, has attracted considerable attention and found potential applications in various research fields such as materials science, organic synthesis, medicinal chemistry, and chemical biology. Thus, far, a large number of copper­(I) catalysts have been explored for the AAC reaction, including simple Cu­(I) salts, organometallic Cu­(I) precatalysts, and nanostructured copper­(I) catalysts et al. Among them, homogeneous copper­(I) catalysts have been widely developed to catalyze AAC reactions. Nevertheless, in view of environment and economics, homogeneous catalysts may easily be destroyed during the catalytic reaction and not be easily recovered after the catalytic reaction for recycling use. In contrast, the utilization of heterogeneous copper­(I) catalysts can offer several advantages, for example, high reusability, easy catalyst/product separation, high catalytic performance, and improved stability. In this regard, Cu­(I) species coating onto various supports have been well explored as heterogeneous catalysts for the CuAAC reactions. However, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), especially polyoxometalates (POMs)-based Cu­(I)-MOFs, were rarely employed as promising heterogeneous catalysts for the copper­(I)-catalyzed “‘click’” reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Copper(I)-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC), as a powerful one-pot "click" reaction, has attracted considerable attention and found potential applications in various research fields such as materials science, organic synthesis, medicinal chemistry, and chemical biology. Thus, far, a large number of copper(I) catalysts have been explored for the AAC reaction, including simple Cu(I) salts, organometallic Cu(I) precatalysts, and nanostructured copper(I) catalysts et al. Among them, homogeneous copper(I) catalysts have been widely developed to catalyze AAC reactions. Nevertheless, in view of environment and economics, homogeneous catalysts may easily be destroyed during the catalytic reaction and not be easily recovered after the catalytic reaction for recycling use. In contrast, the utilization of heterogeneous copper(I) catalysts can offer several advantages, for example, high reusability, easy catalyst/product separation, high catalytic performance, and improved stability. In this regard, Cu(I) species coating onto various supports have been well explored as heterogeneous catalysts for the CuAAC reactions. However, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), especially polyoxometalates (POMs)-based Cu(I)-MOFs, were rarely employed as promising heterogeneous catalysts for the copper(I)-catalyzed "‘click'" reactions.

elements.content: MOFs as an emerging functional material exhibit great promise in the fields of gas storage, molecular sensing, separation, electronics, and catalysis, among others. In this facet, the versatility in the active sites of the MOFs has resulted in their applications in various sectors of catalysis, such as Brønsted acid and Lewis acid catalysis, photocatalysis, oxidations, hydrogenations, and asymmetrical catalysis et al. Nevertheless, a plenty of MOFs usually show the relatively low stability, which limits their further potential applications in catalysis. Alternatively, the introduction of POMs into the MOFs at the molecular level provides a promising way to possibly increase their stability.
elements.clean_text: MOFs as an emerging functional material exhibit great promise in the fields of gas storage, molecular sensing, separation, electronics, and catalysis, among others. In this facet, the versatility in the active sites of the MOFs has resulted in their applications in various sectors of catalysis, such as Brønsted acid and Lewis acid catalysis, photocatalysis, oxidations, hydrogenations, and asymmetrical catalysis et al. Nevertheless, a plenty of MOFs usually show the relatively low stability, which limits their further potential applications in catalysis. Alternatively, the introduction of POMs into the MOFs at the molecular level provides a promising way to possibly increase their stability.

elements.content: Based on above consideration, a new POMs-based Cu­(I)-MOF, namely, [CuI 4(SiW12O40)­(L)]·6H2O·2DMF (1), was achieved by incorporating Keggin-type POMs anions, copper ions, and a functionalized wheel-like resorcin[4]­arene-based ligand (L) under solvothermal condition (). Its crystal structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and further characterized physically. Remarkably, 1 exhibits ultrahigh stability in various organic solvents and aqueous solutions with a wide pH range from 2 to 14. Most importantly, 1 behaves excellent catalytic capability for the ACC reaction as a recycled heterogeneous catalyst.
elements.clean_text: Based on above consideration, a new POMs-based Cu(I)-MOF, namely, [CuI 4(SiW12O40)(L)]⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (1), was achieved by incorporating Keggin-type POMs anions, copper ions, and a functionalized wheel-like resorcin[4]arene-based ligand (L) under solvothermal condition (). Its crystal structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and further characterized physically. Remarkably, 1 exhibits ultrahigh stability in various organic solvents and aqueous solutions with a wide pH range from 2 to 14. Most importantly, 1 behaves excellent catalytic capability for the ACC reaction as a recycled heterogeneous catalyst.

elements.clean_text: 1  Resorcin[4]arene-Based Ligand (L)

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially obtained and were employed without purification. The resorcin[4]­arene-based ligand L and azides were prepared according to the reported procedure. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were determined in CDCl3 on a Bruker 600 MHz. IR spectra were recorded on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. Elemental analysis data (C, H, and N) were measured on a Euro vector EA3000 analyzer. The conversion yields of the AAC reactions were determined by GC equipment with capillary (30 m long ×0.25 mm i.d., WondaCap 17) and FID detector (GC-2014C, Shimadzu, Japan). ICP data were determined on a Leeman Laboratories Prodigy inductively coupled plasma-optical atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were commercially obtained and were employed without purification. The resorcin[4]arene-based ligand L and azides were prepared according to the reported procedure. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were determined in CDCl3 on a Bruker 600 MHz. IR spectra were recorded on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. Elemental analysis data (C, H, and N) were measured on a Euro vector EA3000 analyzer. The conversion yields of the AAC reactions were determined by GC equipment with capillary (30 m long ×0.25 mm i.d., WondaCap 17) and FID detector (GC-2014C, Shimadzu, Japan). ICP data were determined on a Leeman Laboratories Prodigy inductively coupled plasma-optical atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES).

elements.content: Crystallographic data of 1 was collected on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXS-2014 crystallographic software package. The SQUEEZE function in PLATON was utilized because of the highly disordered solvents. All the non-H atoms were located from the difference Fourier map and refined anisotropically. Crystallographic data are listed in Tables S1 and S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data of 1 was collected on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXS-2014 crystallographic software package. The SQUEEZE function in PLATON was utilized because of the highly disordered solvents. All the non-H atoms were located from the difference Fourier map and refined anisotropically. Crystallographic data are listed in Tables S1 and S2.

elements.content: A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (14 mg, 0.08 mmol), L (23 mg, 0.01 mmol), H4SiW12O40·xH2O (40 mg, 0.014 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (4 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 1 were achieved in a yield of 45% based on L. Anal. Calcd for C146H154N26O56Cu4SiW12 (M r = 5657.39): C, 30.99; H, 2.74; N, 6.43. Found: C, 30.61; H, 2.63; N, 6.12. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2959 (m), 2873 (m), 1585 (w), 1467 (m), 1381 (w), 1287 (m), 1181 (w), 1093 (w), 1011 (w), 968 (s), 920 (s), 881 (m), 803 (s), 696 (s), 525 (m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cu4L(SiW12O40)]⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (1)

A mixture of CuCl2⋅2H2O (14 mg, 0.08 mmol), L (23 mg, 0.01 mmol), H4SiW12O40⋅xH2O (40 mg, 0.014 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (4 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 1 were achieved in a yield of 45% based on L. Anal. Calcd for C146H154N26O56Cu4SiW12 (M r = 5657.39): C, 30.99; H, 2.74; N, 6.43. Found: C, 30.61; H, 2.63; N, 6.12. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2959 (m), 2873 (m), 1585 (w), 1467 (m), 1381 (w), 1287 (m), 1181 (w), 1093 (w), 1011 (w), 968 (s), 920 (s), 881 (m), 803 (s), 696 (s), 525 (m).

elements.content: A mixture of azides (1 mmol), alkynes (2 mmol), amyl acetate (0.92 mmol), 1 (30 mg, 0.0053 mmol), and methanol (4 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL pressure-proof pipe. The resulting mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. The product yields were measured by GC and further confirmed by 1H NMR and 13C NMR (Figures S1–S22).
elements.clean_text:
Procedure for the CuAAC Reactions Catalyzed by 1 

A mixture of azides (1 mmol), alkynes (2 mmol), amyl acetate (0.92 mmol), 1 (30 mg, 0.0053 mmol), and methanol (4 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL pressure-proof pipe. The resulting mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. The product yields were measured by GC and further confirmed by 1H NMR and 13C NMR (Figures S1-S22).

elements.content: The block-shaped crystal samples of 1 were prepared under solvothermal condition. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. SQUEEZE routine in PLATON was utilized during the refinement and the disordered solvents were established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis. As shown in a, asymmetric unit of 1 is composed of two Cu­(I) cations, half a L ligand, half a [SiW12O40]4– anion, three free water molecules, and one N,N′-dimethylforamide (DMF) molecule. Two Cu­(I) cations exhibit distinct coordination spheres: Cu1 is coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from two L ligands in a T-shaped coordination geometry, while Cu2 is surrounded by four nitrogen atoms from three L ligands in a tetrahedral coordination sphere. As illustrated in b, every L ligand bridges eight Cu­(I) cations. In this manner, adjacent Cu­(I) cations are linked by the L ligands to afford a 2D layer (c). Furthermore, adjacent layers are interconnected each other through π–π interactions between the 2-(1H-imidazol-2-yl)­pyridine groups (centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.75 Å, centroid-to-plane distance of 3.56 Å, dihedral angle of 11.26°), leading to a fascinating 3D supramolecular architecture (d). It is interesting to note that the [SiW12O40]4– anions were sandwiched into adjacent layers (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [CuI 4(SiW12O40)(L)]⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (1)

The block-shaped crystal samples of 1 were prepared under solvothermal condition. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. SQUEEZE routine in PLATON was utilized during the refinement and the disordered solvents were established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis. As shown in a, asymmetric unit of 1 is composed of two Cu(I) cations, half a L ligand, half a [SiW12O40]4- anion, three free water molecules, and one N,N'-dimethylforamide (DMF) molecule. Two Cu(I) cations exhibit distinct coordination spheres: Cu1 is coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from two L ligands in a T-shaped coordination geometry, while Cu2 is surrounded by four nitrogen atoms from three L ligands in a tetrahedral coordination sphere. As illustrated in b, every L ligand bridges eight Cu(I) cations. In this manner, adjacent Cu(I) cations are linked by the L ligands to afford a 2D layer (c). Furthermore, adjacent layers are interconnected each other through π-π interactions between the 2-(1H-imidazol-2-yl)pyridine groups (centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.75 Å, centroid-to-plane distance of 3.56 Å, dihedral angle of 11.26°), leading to a fascinating 3D supramolecular architecture (d). It is interesting to note that the [SiW12O40]4- anions were sandwiched into adjacent layers (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of Cu­(I) in 1. (b) Coordination mode of L in 1. (c) View of the 2D layer structure of 1 along the c axis. (d) View of the 3D supramolecular architecture of 1 along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environments of Cu(I) in 1. (b) Coordination mode of L in 1. (c) View of the 2D layer structure of 1 along the c axis. (d) View of the 3D supramolecular architecture of 1 along the a axis.

elements.content: To investigate the chemical stability of catalyst 1, we soaked freshly prepared 1 in various solvents for 24 h, including DMF, acetonitrile, cyclohexane, ethanol, dichloromethane, acetone, and methanol. It is noteworthy that PXRD patterns of soaked 1 are identical to the simulated one, as shown in , suggesting the outstanding stability of 1 in various organic solvents. Furthermore, the chemical stability of 1 was tested by soaking 1 in aqueous solutions with a wide range of pH values for 24 h. As illustrated in , the PXRD patterns demonstrated that the crystallinity of 1 was well-maintained after immersing 1 in aqueous solutions with pH values ranging from 2 to 14. Moreover, the PXRD pattern of the activated samples of 1 corresponds well to that of the original framework structure, verifying the structural stability of 1 after removing the solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Chemical Stability

To investigate the chemical stability of catalyst 1, we soaked freshly prepared 1 in various solvents for 24 h, including DMF, acetonitrile, cyclohexane, ethanol, dichloromethane, acetone, and methanol. It is noteworthy that PXRD patterns of soaked 1 are identical to the simulated one, as shown in , suggesting the outstanding stability of 1 in various organic solvents. Furthermore, the chemical stability of 1 was tested by soaking 1 in aqueous solutions with a wide range of pH values for 24 h. As illustrated in , the PXRD patterns demonstrated that the crystallinity of 1 was well-maintained after immersing 1 in aqueous solutions with pH values ranging from 2 to 14. Moreover, the PXRD pattern of the activated samples of 1 corresponds well to that of the original framework structure, verifying the structural stability of 1 after removing the solvents.

elements.content: The as-prepared 1 possesses exceptionally chemical stability and is completely insoluble in organic solvents. The high stability of 1 made it a possible stable heterogeneous catalyst in various organic solvents and broad temperature ranges. Recently, CuAAC reaction has been widely utilized in medicinal chemistry, organic synthesis, and polymer chemistry. In view of the catalytically active Cu­(I) sites in 1, we performed a systematic investigation on the cycloaddition reaction between alkyne and azide catalyzed by 1.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Azide-Alkyne "Click" Reaction

The as-prepared 1 possesses exceptionally chemical stability and is completely insoluble in organic solvents. The high stability of 1 made it a possible stable heterogeneous catalyst in various organic solvents and broad temperature ranges. Recently, CuAAC reaction has been widely utilized in medicinal chemistry, organic synthesis, and polymer chemistry. In view of the catalytically active Cu(I) sites in 1, we performed a systematic investigation on the cycloaddition reaction between alkyne and azide catalyzed by 1.

elements.content: Prior to catalytic study, the samples of 1 were soaked in acetone for 24 h and then degassed at 393 K under vacuum for 12 h to acquire the activated samples of 1. At the beginning, the typical reaction between the benzyl azide and phenylacetylene was studied in the presence of catalyst 1 (0.0053 mmol) in methanol at 25 °C for 12 h, as shown in . Nevertheless, only trace products were achieved under this reaction condition (entry 1 in ; Figure S23a). Thus, the catalytic reaction temperatures were elevated from 25 °C to 50 and 80 °C, respectively. Accordingly, the corresponding conversions were enhanced to 44 and 99%, respectively (entries 2 and 3 in ; Figure S23b,c), with increasing temperatures. It is noteworthy that only the single catalytic product 1,4-substituted 1-benzyl-4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazole was obtained by utilizing 1 as catalyst. To further explore effect of the catalyst amount on the conversion yields, the catalyst loading was enhanced from 5 to 30 mg. As a result, the conversion yields were increased from 33 to 99% (entries 3–6 in ; Figure S23c–f) with the increasing loading amount of catalyst 1. However, no obviously elevated conversion yields were observed after the catalyst amount was more than 30 mg. Moreover, the catalytic reaction was conducted in different organic solvents, as shown in . We find that the catalytic conversion yields in ethanol and methanol are much higher than those in other organic solvents, such as dichloromethane, toluene and acetonitrile (entries 7–10 in ; Figure S23g–j).
elements.clean_text: Prior to catalytic study, the samples of 1 were soaked in acetone for 24 h and then degassed at 393 K under vacuum for 12 h to acquire the activated samples of 1. At the beginning, the typical reaction between the benzyl azide and phenylacetylene was studied in the presence of catalyst 1 (0.0053 mmol) in methanol at 25 °C for 12 h, as shown in . Nevertheless, only trace products were achieved under this reaction condition (entry 1 in ; Figure S23a). Thus, the catalytic reaction temperatures were elevated from 25 °C to 50 and 80 °C, respectively. Accordingly, the corresponding conversions were enhanced to 44 and 99%, respectively (entries 2 and 3 in ; Figure S23b,c), with increasing temperatures. It is noteworthy that only the single catalytic product 1,4-substituted 1-benzyl-4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazole was obtained by utilizing 1 as catalyst. To further explore effect of the catalyst amount on the conversion yields, the catalyst loading was enhanced from 5 to 30 mg. As a result, the conversion yields were increased from 33 to 99% (entries 3-6 in ; Figure S23c-f) with the increasing loading amount of catalyst 1. However, no obviously elevated conversion yields were observed after the catalyst amount was more than 30 mg. Moreover, the catalytic reaction was conducted in different organic solvents, as shown in . We find that the catalytic conversion yields in ethanol and methanol are much higher than those in other organic solvents, such as dichloromethane, toluene and acetonitrile (entries 7-10 in ; Figure S23g-j).

elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic Representation of the "Click" Reaction between Phenylacetylene and Benzyl Azide

elements.content:
Catalytic Reactions of Benzyl Azide with Phenylacetylene under Different Conditions<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> entry catalyst 1 (mg) temperature (°C) solvent conversion (%) 1 30 25 CH3OH trace 2 30 50 CH3OH 44 3 30 80 CH3OH 99 4 5 80 CH3OH 33 5 10 80 CH3OH 63 6 20 80 CH3OH 88 7 30 80 CH3CH2OH 99 8 30 80 CH2Cl2 42 9 30 80 C6H5CH3 34 10 30 80 CH3CN 47

Reaction conditions: benzyl azide (133 mg, 1 mmol), phenylacetylene (204 mg, 2 mmol), amyl acetate (120 mg, 0.92 mmol), and reaction time (12 h).

Isolated yields were calculated by GC and the amyl acetate was employed as the internal standard.

The reaction kinetics between phenylacetylene and benzyl azide were also explored under the optimum reaction condition. The reaction was carried out with the fixed catalyst 1/substrate ratio of 53:10 000 at 80 °C for 12 h. As shown in , the conversion yield is up to 96% after 8 h and gradually reached to 99% after 12 h (Figure S24a–e). Furthermore, the hot filtration test and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis were conducted to certify the heterogeneous nature of the catalytic reactions. Typically, catalyst 1 was removed after 2 h, and the catalytic reaction was further carried out in the filtrate. As shown in , the increasing conversion yields were observed when subjected to the same conditions for another 10 h. ICP analysis of the supernatants demonstrated no Cu­(I) leaching. The result clearly indicated that the current catalytic reaction is heterogeneous.
elements.clean_text: The reaction kinetics between phenylacetylene and benzyl azide were also explored under the optimum reaction condition. The reaction was carried out with the fixed catalyst 1/substrate ratio of 53:10000 at 80 °C for 12 h. As shown in , the conversion yield is up to 96% after 8 h and gradually reached to 99% after 12 h (Figure S24a-e). Furthermore, the hot filtration test and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis were conducted to certify the heterogeneous nature of the catalytic reactions. Typically, catalyst 1 was removed after 2 h, and the catalytic reaction was further carried out in the filtrate. As shown in , the increasing conversion yields were observed when subjected to the same conditions for another 10 h. ICP analysis of the supernatants demonstrated no Cu(I) leaching. The result clearly indicated that the current catalytic reaction is heterogeneous.

elements.content: Conversion curves of the “click” reaction between phenylacetylene and benzyl azide catalyzed by 1 (red) at different time and the removal of 1 by filtration after 2 h of the reaction (blue).
elements.clean_text: 4  Conversion curves of the "click" reaction between phenylacetylene and benzyl azide catalyzed by 1 (red) at different time and the removal of 1 by filtration after 2 h of the reaction (blue).

elements.content: To further explore the catalytic generality of catalyst 1, various terminal alkynes and azides with variable functional groups, including methoxy-, nitro-, halogen, or methyl moieties, were employed to investigate the catalytic performance under the optimized conditions. As shown in , the catalytic reactions between the alkynes and azides exhibit very high conversion yields for all the selected substrates. The result demonstrates that the electron-donating or -withdrawing groups on the phenyl ring are all suitable substrates for the azide–alkyne “click” reaction by using 1 as catalyst (Figure S25a–j). When substrate 1-(azidomethyl)­benzene reacts with various substituted 1-ethynybenzenes, the conversion yields of the substrates can reach to 99%. As far as the catalytic reaction for the 1-ethynybenzene with various substituted azides is concerned, most of the conversion yields of the substrates are up to 99%. Nevertheless, for the ortho-F-substituted azide substrate, ca. 93% product was achieved after 12 h, which may account for the stereohindrance effect of the F group. The result further indicated that the catalytic reaction behaves a very general substrate scope for different alkynes and azides by using 1 as catalyst.
elements.clean_text: To further explore the catalytic generality of catalyst 1, various terminal alkynes and azides with variable functional groups, including methoxy-, nitro-, halogen, or methyl moieties, were employed to investigate the catalytic performance under the optimized conditions. As shown in , the catalytic reactions between the alkynes and azides exhibit very high conversion yields for all the selected substrates. The result demonstrates that the electron-donating or -withdrawing groups on the phenyl ring are all suitable substrates for the azide-alkyne "click" reaction by using 1 as catalyst (Figure S25a-j). When substrate 1-(azidomethyl)benzene reacts with various substituted 1-ethynybenzenes, the conversion yields of the substrates can reach to 99%. As far as the catalytic reaction for the 1-ethynybenzene with various substituted azides is concerned, most of the conversion yields of the substrates are up to 99%. Nevertheless, for the ortho-F-substituted azide substrate, ca. 93% product was achieved after 12 h, which may account for the stereohindrance effect of the F group. The result further indicated that the catalytic reaction behaves a very general substrate scope for different alkynes and azides by using 1 as catalyst.

elements.content:
Catalytic Reactions of the Substituted Benzyl Azides and Phenylacetylenes Catalyzed by <bold>1</bold> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t2fn1"></xref>

Reaction conditions: 1 (30 mg, 0.0053 mmol), azide (1 mmol), alkyne (2 mmol), amyl acetate (120 mg, 0.92 mmol), and 80 °C.

Isolated yields were calculated by GC, and amyl acetate was employed as the internal standard.

Moreover, the recyclability and stability is an essential feature of any catalysts that are potential for use in industrial applications. Therefore, the recycling experiments were carried out after the catalyst 1 was recovered from the “click” reaction through a washing and drying process. Catalyst 1 can be easily separated by simple filtration and washed with dichloromethane three times, and reused for five consecutive cycles without obvious loss in the catalytic activity ( and S26a–e). Moreover, the PXRD pattern of 1 after being recycled five times is in good agreement with the simulated one (), demonstrating that the crystallinity and structural integrity of catalyst 1 were well remained during the recycle catalytic processes.

Therefore, the recycling experiments were carried out after the catalyst 1 was recovered from the "click" reaction through a washing and drying process. Catalyst 1 can be easily separated by simple filtration and washed with dichloromethane three times, and reused for five consecutive cycles without obvious loss in the catalytic activity ( and S26a-e). Moreover, the PXRD pattern of 1 after being recycled five times is in good agreement with the simulated one (), demonstrating that the crystallinity and structural integrity of catalyst 1 were well remained during the recycle catalytic processes.

elements.content: Obviously, heterogeneous catalyst 1 has several advantages over the homogeneous copper­(I) catalysts, including separability, recyclability, and stability. For example, 1 can be effectively separated from the reaction system and further applied for the recycling experiments. In comparison with other types of heterogeneous catalysts such as copper­(I) immobilized polymers or copper­(I) modified zeolites, the cycloaddition reaction between the alkyne and azide catalyzed by 1 exhibits the comparable catalytic performance with the elevated reaction temperature and prolonged reaction time. Moreover, the catalytic Cu­(I) sites in catalyst 1 are not easily leached during the catalytic process and can remain the high catalytic activity in the recycling experiments.
elements.clean_text: Obviously, heterogeneous catalyst 1 has several advantages over the homogeneous copper(I) catalysts, including separability, recyclability, and stability. For example, 1 can be effectively separated from the reaction system and further applied for the recycling experiments. In comparison with other types of heterogeneous catalysts such as copper(I) immobilized polymers or copper(I) modified zeolites, the cycloaddition reaction between the alkyne and azide catalyzed by 1 exhibits the comparable catalytic performance with the elevated reaction temperature and prolonged reaction time. Moreover, the catalytic Cu(I) sites in catalyst 1 are not easily leached during the catalytic process and can remain the high catalytic activity in the recycling experiments.

elements.content: On the basis of current catalytic performance and the relative documents, a possible reaction pathway is proposed, as shown in . The Cu­(I) sites in 1 first attack alkyne (A) and then form the Cu­(I)-acetylide intermediate (B) via coordination of the alkyne to the copper­(I). In the next step, the azides react with the Cu­(I)-acetylide intermediate (B) to generate intermediate C. Owing the nucleophilic nature of the terminal N3 in intermediate C, it will attack the C4 position of the alkyne and result in the formation of copper­(I) metallacycle D. Then, the ring contraction occurred in the metallacycle and gave rise to intermediate species E. Finally, the target product 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole was produced by protonation, and catalyst 1 was recovered.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of current catalytic performance and the relative documents, a possible reaction pathway is proposed, as shown in . The Cu(I) sites in 1 first attack alkyne (A) and then form the Cu(I)-acetylide intermediate (B) via coordination of the alkyne to the copper(I). In the next step, the azides react with the Cu(I)-acetylide intermediate (B) to generate intermediate C. Owing the nucleophilic nature of the terminal N3 in intermediate C, it will attack the C4 position of the alkyne and result in the formation of copper(I) metallacycle D. Then, the ring contraction occurred in the metallacycle and gave rise to intermediate species E. Finally, the target product 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole was produced by protonation, and catalyst 1 was recovered.

Proposed Catalytic Mechanism for the CuAAC Reaction by Using Catalyst <bold>1</bold> <xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch3-fn1"></xref>

A–E represent the catalytic intermediates.
elements.clean_text: 3  Proposed Catalytic Mechanism for the CuAAC Reaction by Using Catalyst 1       a  A-E represent the catalytic intermediates.

elements.content:
A–E represent the catalytic intermediates.

Conclusions

In summary, a new POMs-based Cu­(I)-MOF was sovothermally prepared by incorporating the resorcin[4]­arene-functionalized multinitrogen chelating ligand. In 1, neighboring Cu­(I) cations were linked by L ligands into a 2D layer, which are further interconnected each other through π–π interactions to afford a fascinating 3D supramolecular architecture sandwiched by POMs anions. Strikingly, 1 exhibited exceptional chemical stability in organic solvents or aqueous solutions with a wide pH range from 2 to 14. The catalytically active Cu­(I) sites of activated 1 make it an excellent heterogeneous catalyst for the ACC reaction. Significantly, catalyst 1 could be easily separated and recycled, and its activity exhibited no obvious decreases during the next cycles of reactions.
elements.clean_text:
a  A-E represent the catalytic intermediates.  

Conclusions

In summary, a new POMs-based Cu(I)-MOF was sovothermally prepared by incorporating the resorcin[4]arene-functionalized multinitrogen chelating ligand. In 1, neighboring Cu(I) cations were linked by L ligands into a 2D layer, which are further interconnected each other through π-π interactions to afford a fascinating 3D supramolecular architecture sandwiched by POMs anions. Strikingly, 1 exhibited exceptional chemical stability in organic solvents or aqueous solutions with a wide pH range from 2 to 14. The catalytically active Cu(I) sites of activated 1 make it an excellent heterogeneous catalyst for the ACC reaction. Significantly, catalyst 1 could be easily separated and recycled, and its activity exhibited no obvious decreases during the next cycles of reactions.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (14 mg, 0.08 mmol), L (23 mg, 0.01 mmol), H4SiW12O40·xH2O (40 mg, 0.014 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (4 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 1 were achieved in a yield of 45% based on L. Anal. Calcd for C146H154N26O56Cu4SiW12 (M r = 5657.39): C, 30.99; H, 2.74; N, 6.43. Found: C, 30.61; H, 2.63; N, 6.12. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2959 (m), 2873 (m), 1585 (w), 1467 (m), 1381 (w), 1287 (m), 1181 (w), 1093 (w), 1011 (w), 968 (s), 920 (s), 881 (m), 803 (s), 696 (s), 525 (m).

Synthesis of [Cu4L(SiW12O40)]⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (1)

A mixture of CuCl2⋅2H2O (14 mg, 0.08 mmol), L (23 mg, 0.01 mmol), H4SiW12O40⋅xH2O (40 mg, 0.014 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and ethanol (4 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 1 were achieved in a yield of 45% based on L. Anal. Calcd for C146H154N26O56Cu4SiW12 (M r = 5657.39): C, 30.99; H, 2.74; N, 6.43. Found: C, 30.61; H, 2.63; N, 6.12. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2959 (m), 2873 (m), 1585 (w), 1467 (m), 1381 (w), 1287 (m), 1181 (w), 1093 (w), 1011 (w), 968 (s), 920 (s), 881 (m), 803 (s), 696 (s), 525 (m).

metadata.title:
Highly
Stable Copper(I)-Based Metal–Organic Framework Assembled with
Resorcin[4]arene and Polyoxometalate for Efficient Heterogeneous Catalysis
of Azide–Alkyne “Click” Reaction
